blog.name: parker-photography
blog.title: Parker Photography
blog.description: A PhotoMode collection from Marvel's Spider-Man (PS4)

summary: Sorry to drop in like this...
caption: Sorry to drop in like this…

summary: A drunken ramble whilst drinking Baileys: I want to see Spider man into the spider verse. I want to see the spider man. I like...
body:
A drunken ramble whilst drinking Baileys:

I want to see Spider man into the spider verse. I want to see the spider man. I like spider man. It has Miles Morales in it, and I like him, as spider man. I like spider man. I used to watch spider man. I used to watch the spider man as a child. I used to watch the spiderman with the weird 90s theme song, with the electric guitar solo, and the strange synth beats, and the use of the word spider man over and over again rather than the actual lyrics from the original spider man. I like spider man, I want to see the spider man. I will see the spider man…. I rest my case.

blog.name: fourtristattoos
blog.title: Fourtristattoos
blog.description:
S. Gryffindor. I write lots of AU's. Chest Hair lover Judy Hopps energy

masterlist ♡ writing playlist ♡ faq’s

(theme images not mine)

title: Loosing You (P.P. Fic)
body:
**{All story, characters, ideas, and everything in-between on Spiderman belong to Marvel. This is merely a fic.} **

[So, this is a new fic, for University!Peter, and it’s got a little angst in it? I don’t know. Fluff and angst, a little fighting but not anything crazy at all.]

-      Prompt from @witterprompts “Pretending I can’t here you has worked surprising well.”

Masterlist 

{Picture/Gif credits to poster/creator @bnsplmn }

Loosing You

Peter tried to stay away from (Y/N). He tired his hardest to not stare at her while she walked through the halls, he tried to leave class slightly late so he could walk behind her, and he tried his very hardest to not be near her when she was alone. He knew, if he ever talked to her again, it would only be a fight. Whenever he saw her, the memories of the night he accidently almostgot her killed, and then proceeded to unmask himself to her, only resulting in a slap in the face, he knew their relationship would never be the same.

“You’d think the person you’re best friends with, would have the balls to at least tell their friend something!” She had yelled at him in the middle of that New York alley behind the Chinese takeout restaurant she loved. “You’d think that I would’ve meant something, anything! I could’ve been killed tonight, and then this?”

Peter tried to explain to her, tried in his best manner to help her understand why he thought not telling her was the best idea. ‘Because I’m in love with you!’ his brain yelled at him. But no, his response being that she would have been better off without knowing, a scoff from her as a response, then a slap.

He never knew how undeniably in love he was with (Y/N) until after that night. He couldn’t get her off of his mind, couldn’t stop yearning to talk to her again. He lazily stared at the chemistry homework on the library table, eyeing the numbers and letters with intense hatred. He groaned aloud, letting his hand go, which supported his head, and hit his forehead on the table. Hissing, he moved up slightly and rubbed the front of his face, eyes squinting. He then noticed (Y/N), standing a few bookcases down, watching him. She had on the University’s purple emblem sweater with a grey skirt that fanned just below her mid-thigh, and her hair was pinned in a loose low bun. Peter felt his heart constrict, and when she saw him looking back, she turned her head as though she was never looking.

He couldn’t take it anymore. He had to say something to her. It had been far too long. Peter rose from the table and set his pencil down next to the papers. He cleared his throat and moved down the path and towards (Y/N) next to the bookcase. He shuffled up to her, and coughed awkwardly, looking at her beautiful face. She stayed silent, ignoring him.

Peter sighed and rubbed a hand over his face. “(Y/N), please, talk to me.” Still he had no response from her as she scanned the book bindings. “(Y/N), this isn’t working. Please, can we stop this?”

“Pretending I can’t hear you, has actually worked surprisingly well so far,” she stated pitilessly without looking at him, pulling a book from the bookcase out, right in front of his face. He jerked back, a frown forming on his lips.

“(Y/N) c’mon,” he preened, walked after her. He didn’t care about his homework at this point.

“Peter, just go…make a web or something. I don’t care.”

Peter groaned and stopped in front of the desk in which she slid into. She sighed and pulled her black thinly rimmed glasses out of her purse and pressed them to her face, opening the book and taking out her notepad. Peter slid into the chair across from her, staring.

“(Y/N), I’m sorry.” He said, his eyes pleading to her. “Please, can we maybe, I don’t know, get food tonight, and talk about it?”

She paused for a moment, then looked up, her eyes wavering. “I have a date. With Jonas Mathers, at King Garden tonight.”

Peter almost choked. Jonas Mathers? Of course, she would be going out with the star baseball player, of courseshe would have a date. He wanted to throw himself into the nearest trash can and hide in there for the rest of his life.

“That’s…nice,” he coughed out, looking down from the window beside them. She looked at him, a frown gracing her lips. She sighed and looked down at the book, not pushing anymore conversation.

“Well, uh,” he said awkwardly, pushing himself out of the chair and looking to the ground. “Have fun with that.”

She nodded, obviously not reading the book, but not looking at Peter at all. He closed his eyes and turned around, walking back to his desk like a fool. ‘Turn around, and tell her how you feel!’ His brain screamed at him. Yet, no change occurred in his steps, and soon he found himself walking out of the library, backpack in tow, towards the subway.

Later that evening, Peter sat in the living room of his shared apartment with Ned, who was currently out of town and in visits with his family. Peter clicked through his pictures on his laptop, the daily evening news playing in front of him on the television. He looked at the faces; him, Ned, and (Y/N) smiling and laughing. He remembered the day he took these pictures in Central Park. The sun was full and bright, and the air wasn’t humid or wet. There was a cool summer breeze, and the fountain looked extra sparkling. (Y/N) stepped around the top of the fountain like a ballerina, her yellow and pink dress bright in the sun. Peter sighed and shut the laptop, laying his head back against the cough and closing his eyes.

“We have breaking news here, just coming in from our onsite reporter,” the television spoke. “There is an armed robbery taking place on Adams and 15th street, currently two fatalities and police are at a standstill. There are hostages inside.”

Peter’s eyes flew open and he stood in the living room. On the television, images of the robbery were in place, and Peter knew just were that was. King Garden. There was a bank just down the block, and Peter believed it logical that whoever perpetrated the attack, would have ran down the street, probably cornered by police, and went into the restaurant. He jumped around the couch, ran into is room, pulled out his suit and slipped it on, opening his window and slinging out, flying down the streets in hopes he could make it in time.

When Peter finally came across the restaurant, he had been right. The place was swarmed by cops, and gun fire admitted every so often. He narrowed his eyes, looking down and numbering how may forces were on the ground, then decided his best bet was flying to the side of the building to not attract unwanted attention, and come in through the kitchen. He knew the backdoor was probably locked, but he could find a way in. He lifted his hand and flung himself on the web over the buildings and around the corners. He slid onto the ground, grabbing onto the side restaurant door and snapping the handle off, kicking the door forward and walked into the kitchen. There were no people in the room. Probably all held in the front, he affirmed, walking down the empty kitchen and towards the entrance of the dining room. He looked out the window on the kitchen door, scanning the group of customers, and the robber who sat behind the hostess desk. Then, on the side of the room, Peter noticed the familiar form and face of (Y/N), huddled underneath a table and holding her legs to her chest. Jonas sat opposite of her, pressed against the wall. She looked around nervously, then, her eyes fell to the kitchen door and they widened. Peter shook his head, raising a finger to his lips. She nodded slightly, making no noise.

He took a breath, pulled his fist back, and slammed it into the window, a crash emitting from the door. The robber turned their head, shouting. Shot fired from the police cars, and the customers screamed, pulling their hands over their head. Peter retracted his hand and pulled his fingers in, zipping a web out and pulling the weapon from the robber’s hands and slamming it against the door, crashing in minuscule pieces. He kicked open the door, and shot more webs towards the robber, yelling at the customers to get out through the back door. They all ran behind him, and Peter tied the robber to the desk with ease. He punched the criminal down, and stuck his webs to the desk, clipping the robber’s hands together and tying them down. The police outside grabbed the customers, calming them down and calling dispatch on the updates. Peter walked away from the robber and ran out the back door, leaving the Police to collect the felon.

He swung himself down the streets, the wind breezing through his suit. Making his way to the apartment, he slid himself through the open window and hit against his bed. He pulled the top of the suit off, running and hand through his hair. He walked into the bathroom, running water over his face and taking a deep breath before drying and walking into the living room area. He walked over to the kitchen, pulling out a soda and popping the top off, gulping the sugary drink down in a hurry. His heart was racing, still not used to the feeling of seeing (Y/N) in the restaurant. People being interviewed on the television, spouting praises of him, or better his alter-ego, but he ignored them and closed his eyes, shivering slightly at the sound of the doorbell. His eyes widened and he struggled pulling off the suit and throwing it into his room, pulling on his old high school spirit shirt and a pair of gray sweats. He ran to the door and opened it wide, staring blankly at (Y/N) who stood in the middle of the frame.

“(Y/N), what are you—”

She pushed forward, wrapping her arms around his neck and pressing her lips to his. His heart stopped, and he wrapped his arms around her waist securely. He felt small tears drip onto his cheeks from her eyes as she squinted them shut, and he rubbed her back softly. She pulled her face back and tucked it into the crook of his neck, hiccupping and wetting his shirt. He closed his eyes and sighed, holding her close.

“I’m sorry, I’m so, so sorry, Peter,” she cried quietly on his shoulder. He frowned and held her tighter.

“You don’t need to apologize,” he whispered, pushing his face into the side of her head, smelling her sweet shampoo and smiling to himself. “I’ll always be there to protect you.”

“It’s not that,” she whispered, pulling away. She looked into his eyes with tears pooling on the rims. “Tonight, I thought I was gonna die, and I realized how much I would miss you, how much it hurt me to not talk to you, to not forgive you. I shouldn’t have gotten mad, I shouldn’t—.”

“Yes, you should have, (Y/N),” he interrupted. “I should have told you. I was being stupid, and I thought I had a better chance at protecting you if you didn’t know. But, I was wrong. I should have talked to you about it.”

He pressed his hands to her cheeks and kissed her forehead. “I can’t lose you, too,” he whispered softly. Tears fell down her face and she pulled him to herself again, sighing and kissing his jaw softly.

“You’ll never lose me.”

Probably all held in the front, he affirmed, walking down the empty kitchen and towards the entrance of the dining room. He looked out the window on the kitchen door, scanning the group of customers, and the robber who sat behind the hostess desk. Then, on the side of the room, Peter noticed the familiar form and face of (Y/N), huddled underneath a table and holding her legs to her chest. Jonas sat opposite of her, pressed against the wall. She looked around nervously, then, her eyes fell to the kitchen door and they widened. Peter shook his head, raising a finger to his lips. She nodded slightly, making no noise.

He took a breath, pulled his fist back, and slammed it into the window, a crash emitting from the door. The robber turned their head, shouting. Shot fired from the police cars, and the customers screamed, pulling their hands over their head. Peter retracted his hand and pulled his fingers in, zipping a web out and pulling the weapon from the robber’s hands and slamming it against the door, crashing in minuscule pieces. He kicked open the door, and shot more webs towards the robber, yelling at the customers to get out through the back door. They all ran behind him, and Peter tied the robber to the desk with ease. He punched the criminal down, and stuck his webs to the desk, clipping the robber’s hands together and tying them down. The police outside grabbed the customers, calming them down and calling dispatch on the updates. Peter walked away from the robber and ran out the back door, leaving the Police to collect the felon.

He swung himself down the streets, the wind breezing through his suit. Making his way to the apartment, he slid himself through the open window and hit against his bed. He pulled the top of the suit off, running and hand through his hair. He walked into the bathroom, running water over his face and taking a deep breath before drying and walking into the living room area. He walked over to the kitchen, pulling out a soda and popping the top off, gulping the sugary drink down in a hurry. His heart was racing, still not used to the feeling of seeing (Y/N) in the restaurant. People being interviewed on the television, spouting praises of him, or better his alter-ego, but he ignored them and closed his eyes, shivering slightly at the sound of the doorbell. His eyes widened and he struggled pulling off the suit and throwing it into his room, pulling on his old high school spirit shirt and a pair of gray sweats. He ran to the door and opened it wide, staring blankly at (Y/N) who stood in the middle of the frame.

“(Y/N), what are you—”

She pushed forward, wrapping her arms around his neck and pressing her lips to his. His heart stopped, and he wrapped his arms around her waist securely. He felt small tears drip onto his cheeks from her eyes as she squinted them shut, and he rubbed her back softly. She pulled her face back and tucked it into the crook of his neck, hiccupping and wetting his shirt. He closed his eyes and sighed, holding her close.

“I’m sorry, I’m so, so sorry, Peter,” she cried quietly on his shoulder. He frowned and held her tighter.

“You don’t need to apologize,” he whispered, pushing his face into the side of her head, smelling her sweet shampoo and smiling to himself. “I’ll always be there to protect you.”

“It’s not that,” she whispered, pulling away. She looked into his eyes with tears pooling on the rims. “Tonight, I thought I was gonna die, and I realized how much I would miss you, how much it hurt me to not talk to you, to not forgive you. I shouldn’t have gotten mad, I shouldn’t—.”

“Yes, you should have, (Y/N),” he interrupted. “I should have told you. I was being stupid, and I thought I had a better chance at protecting you if you didn’t know. But, I was wrong. I should have talked to you about it.”

He pressed his hands to her cheeks and kissed her forehead. “I can’t lose you, too,” he whispered softly. Tears fell down her face and she pulled him to herself again, sighing and kissing his jaw softly.

“You’ll never lose me.”
trail.content:
**{All story, characters, ideas, and everything in-between on Spiderman belong to Marvel. This is merely a fic.} **

[So, this is a new fic, for University!Peter, and it’s got a little angst in it? I don’t know. Fluff and angst, a little fighting but not anything crazy at all.]

-      Prompt from @witterprompts “Pretending I can’t here you has worked surprising well.”

Masterlist 

{Picture/Gif credits to poster/creator @bnsplmn }

Loosing You

Peter tried to stay away from (Y/N). He tired his hardest to not stare at her while she walked through the halls, he tried to leave class slightly late so he could walk behind her, and he tried his very hardest to not be near her when she was alone. He knew, if he ever talked to her again, it would only be a fight. Whenever he saw her, the memories of the night he accidently almostgot her killed, and then proceeded to unmask himself to her, only resulting in a slap in the face, he knew their relationship would never be the same.

“You’d think the person you’re best friends with, would have the balls to at least tell their friend something!” She had yelled at him in the middle of that New York alley behind the Chinese takeout restaurant she loved. “You’d think that I would’ve meant something, anything! I could’ve been killed tonight, and then this?”

Peter tried to explain to her, tried in his best manner to help her understand why he thought not telling her was the best idea. ‘Because I’m in love with you!’ his brain yelled at him. But no, his response being that she would have been better off without knowing, a scoff from her as a response, then a slap.

He never knew how undeniably in love he was with (Y/N) until after that night. He couldn’t get her off of his mind, couldn’t stop yearning to talk to her again. He lazily stared at the chemistry homework on the library table, eyeing the numbers and letters with intense hatred. He groaned aloud, letting his hand go, which supported his head, and hit his forehead on the table. Hissing, he moved up slightly and rubbed the front of his face, eyes squinting. He then noticed (Y/N), standing a few bookcases down, watching him. She had on the University’s purple emblem sweater with a grey skirt that fanned just below her mid-thigh, and her hair was pinned in a loose low bun. Peter felt his heart constrict, and when she saw him looking back, she turned her head as though she was never looking.

He couldn’t take it anymore. He had to say something to her. It had been far too long. Peter rose from the table and set his pencil down next to the papers. He cleared his throat and moved down the path and towards (Y/N) next to the bookcase. He shuffled up to her, and coughed awkwardly, looking at her beautiful face. She stayed silent, ignoring him.

Peter sighed and rubbed a hand over his face. “(Y/N), please, talk to me.” Still he had no response from her as she scanned the book bindings. “(Y/N), this isn’t working. Please, can we stop this?”

“Pretending I can’t hear you, has actually worked surprisingly well so far,” she stated pitilessly without looking at him, pulling a book from the bookcase out, right in front of his face. He jerked back, a frown forming on his lips.

“(Y/N) c’mon,” he preened, walked after her. He didn’t care about his homework at this point.

“Peter, just go…make a web or something. I don’t care.”

Peter groaned and stopped in front of the desk in which she slid into. She sighed and pulled her black thinly rimmed glasses out of her purse and pressed them to her face, opening the book and taking out her notepad. Peter slid into the chair across from her, staring.

“(Y/N), I’m sorry.” He said, his eyes pleading to her. “Please, can we maybe, I don’t know, get food tonight, and talk about it?”

She paused for a moment, then looked up, her eyes wavering. “I have a date. With Jonas Mathers, at King Garden tonight.”

Peter almost choked. Jonas Mathers? Of course, she would be going out with the star baseball player, of courseshe would have a date. He wanted to throw himself into the nearest trash can and hide in there for the rest of his life.

“That’s…nice,” he coughed out, looking down from the window beside them. She looked at him, a frown gracing her lips. She sighed and looked down at the book, not pushing anymore conversation.

“Well, uh,” he said awkwardly, pushing himself out of the chair and looking to the ground. “Have fun with that.”

She nodded, obviously not reading the book, but not looking at Peter at all. He closed his eyes and turned around, walking back to his desk like a fool. ‘Turn around, and tell her how you feel!’ His brain screamed at him. Yet, no change occurred in his steps, and soon he found himself walking out of the library, backpack in tow, towards the subway.

Later that evening, Peter sat in the living room of his shared apartment with Ned, who was currently out of town and in visits with his family. Peter clicked through his pictures on his laptop, the daily evening news playing in front of him on the television. He looked at the faces; him, Ned, and (Y/N) smiling and laughing. He remembered the day he took these pictures in Central Park. The sun was full and bright, and the air wasn’t humid or wet. There was a cool summer breeze, and the fountain looked extra sparkling. (Y/N) stepped around the top of the fountain like a ballerina, her yellow and pink dress bright in the sun. Peter sighed and shut the laptop, laying his head back against the cough and closing his eyes.

“We have breaking news here, just coming in from our onsite reporter,” the television spoke. “There is an armed robbery taking place on Adams and 15th street, currently two fatalities and police are at a standstill. There are hostages inside.”

Peter’s eyes flew open and he stood in the living room. On the television, images of the robbery were in place, and Peter knew just were that was. King Garden. There was a bank just down the block, and Peter believed it logical that whoever perpetrated the attack, would have ran down the street, probably cornered by police, and went into the restaurant. He jumped around the couch, ran into is room, pulled out his suit and slipped it on, opening his window and slinging out, flying down the streets in hopes he could make it in time.

When Peter finally came across the restaurant, he had been right. The place was swarmed by cops, and gun fire admitted every so often. He narrowed his eyes, looking down and numbering how may forces were on the ground, then decided his best bet was flying to the side of the building to not attract unwanted attention, and come in through the kitchen. He knew the backdoor was probably locked, but he could find a way in. He lifted his hand and flung himself on the web over the buildings and around the corners. He slid onto the ground, grabbing onto the side restaurant door and snapping the handle off, kicking the door forward and walked into the kitchen. There were no people in the room. Probably all held in the front, he affirmed, walking down the empty kitchen and towards the entrance of the dining room. He looked out the window on the kitchen door, scanning the group of customers, and the robber who sat behind the hostess desk. Then, on the side of the room, Peter noticed the familiar form and face of (Y/N), huddled underneath a table and holding her legs to her chest. Jonas sat opposite of her, pressed against the wall. She looked around nervously, then, her eyes fell to the kitchen door and they widened. Peter shook his head, raising a finger to his lips. She nodded slightly, making no noise.

He took a breath, pulled his fist back, and slammed it into the window, a crash emitting from the door. The robber turned their head, shouting. Shot fired from the police cars, and the customers screamed, pulling their hands over their head. Peter retracted his hand and pulled his fingers in, zipping a web out and pulling the weapon from the robber’s hands and slamming it against the door, crashing in minuscule pieces. He kicked open the door, and shot more webs towards the robber, yelling at the customers to get out through the back door. They all ran behind him, and Peter tied the robber to the desk with ease. He punched the criminal down, and stuck his webs to the desk, clipping the robber’s hands together and tying them down. The police outside grabbed the customers, calming them down and calling dispatch on the updates. Peter walked away from the robber and ran out the back door, leaving the Police to collect the felon.

He swung himself down the streets, the wind breezing through his suit. Making his way to the apartment, he slid himself through the open window and hit against his bed. He pulled the top of the suit off, running and hand through his hair. He walked into the bathroom, running water over his face and taking a deep breath before drying and walking into the living room area. He walked over to the kitchen, pulling out a soda and popping the top off, gulping the sugary drink down in a hurry. His heart was racing, still not used to the feeling of seeing (Y/N) in the restaurant. People being interviewed on the television, spouting praises of him, or better his alter-ego, but he ignored them and closed his eyes, shivering slightly at the sound of the doorbell. His eyes widened and he struggled pulling off the suit and throwing it into his room, pulling on his old high school spirit shirt and a pair of gray sweats. He ran to the door and opened it wide, staring blankly at (Y/N) who stood in the middle of the frame.

“(Y/N), what are you—”

She pushed forward, wrapping her arms around his neck and pressing her lips to his. His heart stopped, and he wrapped his arms around her waist securely. He felt small tears drip onto his cheeks from her eyes as she squinted them shut, and he rubbed her back softly. She pulled her face back and tucked it into the crook of his neck, hiccupping and wetting his shirt. He closed his eyes and sighed, holding her close.

“I’m sorry, I’m so, so sorry, Peter,” she cried quietly on his shoulder. He frowned and held her tighter.

“You don’t need to apologize,” he whispered, pushing his face into the side of her head, smelling her sweet shampoo and smiling to himself. “I’ll always be there to protect you.”

“It’s not that,” she whispered, pulling away. She looked into his eyes with tears pooling on the rims. “Tonight, I thought I was gonna die, and I realized how much I would miss you, how much it hurt me to not talk to you, to not forgive you. I shouldn’t have gotten mad, I shouldn’t—.”

“Yes, you should have, (Y/N),” he interrupted. “I should have told you. I was being stupid, and I thought I had a better chance at protecting you if you didn’t know. But, I was wrong. I should have talked to you about it.”

He pressed his hands to her cheeks and kissed her forehead. “I can’t lose you, too,” he whispered softly. Tears fell down her face and she pulled him to herself again, sighing and kissing his jaw softly.

“You’ll never lose me.”

The characters advertised are not an exclusive list, rather they are a short list of suggestions. Our intention is to maintain a rotor of characters from a variety of backgrounds. Please feel free to apply outside of the characters posted here.

summary: Marvel Zombies RP Wanted Connection: Miles Morales Requested by: Peter Parker Telephone networks have failed, the internet is...
caption:
Marvel Zombies RP Wanted Connection: Miles Morales
Requested by: Peter Parker

Telephone networks have failed, the internet is gone.  Modern communication seems to have come to an end.  What remains is radiowaves.  People with the right equipment have begun to communicate with anyone in range using CB radios, walkie talkies, whatever they can get their hands on.  Some are broadcasting, some are just listening.

As he tuned the radio through the various channels, looking for news, Miles heard the end of a series of coordinates.  As the static cleared, a familiar voice sounded, a voice he had not heard in over a year –

This is Peter Parker broadcasting for Miles Morales. I know you are a survivor so you are out there somewhere. This is no city, but its got video games, good people, strong walls and plenty to eat. Also hot showers are a thing here so yeah try to find your way here kid. Us spiders need to stick together.

Marvel Zombies RP is a Marvel Comics AU roleplay established 1 April 2017. We look forward to surviving with you.

summary: Spider-Man: Far From Home Product Tie-In Teases Mysterio's Fishbowl Helmet
title: Spider-Man: Far From Home Product Tie-In Teases Mysterio's Fishbowl Helmet
excerpt: A limited edition flavor of Dr Pepper appears to tease Mysterio's fishbowl helmet in Spider-Man: Far From Home.
description:
When photos from the set of Spider-Man: Far From Home leaked online featuring Jake Gyllenhaal in-costume as Quentin Beck/Mysterio, many fans wondered why he wasn’t wearing the character’s trademark “fishbowl” helmet? Also, would the iconic piece of the villain’s wardrobe would be featured in the film at all?

We might have an answer to those questions, courtesy of a limited edition flavor of Dr Pepper set to be released in 2019 to promote the release of Spidey’s next solo film.

RELATED: Tom Holland Officially Debuts His New Spider-Man Costume

A post from the snack food-based Instagram page candykingsuk features an image of tentative designs for the cans and bottles that will hold Dr Pepper’s new “dark berry” flavored soda. A silhouette can be found on the products that most Spider-Man fans will likely recognize as Mysterio, fishbowl and all.

The is silhouette accompanied by a blue Spider-Man symbol, a Marvel Studios logo and text that reads, “Final design to feature major movie character.” Apart from Spider-Man himself, you can’t really get more “major” than the character who will likely serve as Far From Home’s main villain.

RELATED: Spider-Man: Far From Home Wraps Production

Spider-Man: Far From Home, starring Tom Holland, Zendaya, Jake Gyllenhaal, Marisa Tomei, Samuel L. Jackson and Michael Keaton, is scheduled for release on July 5, 2019.

True story: Spider-Man Homecoming motivated me to actually go to my school’s homecoming dance for my first time
Plus basically...
body:
True story: Spider-Man Homecoming motivated me to actually go to my school’s homecoming dance for my first time


Plus basically the scene with Peter getting prepared with Aunt May after asking Liz out was me preparing myself for homecoming😭

blog.name: pointman74250
blog.title: ULTRA HIP GLORIFIED WRITER
blog.description:
The Blog of Joseph Lewis Szabo III

Writer, Reader, Geek

summary:
Book Review: 11-1-2018 (Originally published on Goodreads)
Spider-Man Noir is one of the best retellings of a comic superhero...
body:
Book Review: Spider-Man Noir by David Hine & Fabrice Sapolsky

Book Review: 11-1-2018 (Originally published on Goodreads)

Spider-Man Noir is one of the best retellings of a comic superhero because we know the original story down to the fine details.

We know who Peter Parker is, how he became the great webslinger, his ill fated Uncle Ben and how Norman Osborn is his worst enemy ever.

In this comic, the time is different, the style is different and the heart of the character - some will absolutely hate this book for this - is different.

If you want your Spider-Man to stay the same, stick with what works for you.

This version of Peter Parker is variation comic and much like variation music, where beforehand knowledge is important, while the song is the same, the notes are simply played differently in his or her own fashion.

What worked for me in this book is not the noir - while the cover says “noir”, it’s not noir, at least not the noir I know - it’s the Great Depression. While it was tragic and painful and I don’t know many people if they had a Time Machine would want to visit that era, it is still damn interesting. I’ve never been quite as thrilled to study this particular American History but this comic makes me want to read about people who lived during that time period, in my home country.

How many comics do you know makes you want to study history about when people were hungry and dying and trying to make a buck for rent?

None!

It did here.

I loved this comic. I want to read the next volume badly and guess what else: it actually ended on the right note as a complete story! There is no, “Wait for Volume Two, then Three, then Four” it is a complete-freakin’-tale with a beginning, middle and end with no money-grab (Well, if you bought this comic issue to issue then yeah, a money-grab, but comics have always been that way…that is one of reasons they are so damned cool, you wait and grow excited until the next issue is in your sweaty, ten-year old hands. Okay: thirty-year old hands.)

Spider-Man Noir was a surprise for me, a really good one. It’s been awhile since Ol’ Pete made me this happy, and strange to because he is not the person I grew up with.
